review.title: The Conference Paper Assignment Problem: Using Order Weighted Averages to Assign Indivisible Goods
review.abstract: Motivated by the common academic problem of allocating papers to referees for conference reviewing we propose a novel mechanism for solving the assignment problem when we have a two sided matching problem with preferences from one side (the agents/reviewers) over the other side (the objects/papers) and both sides have capacity constraints. The assignment problem is a fundamental problem in both computer science and economics with application in many areas including task and resource allocation. We draw inspiration from multi-criteria decision making and voting and use order weighted averages (OWAs) to propose a novel and flexible class of algorithms for the assignment problem. We show an algorithm for finding a $\Sigma$-OWA assignment in polynomial time, in contrast to the NP-hardness of finding an egalitarian assignment. Inspired by this setting we observe an interesting connection between our model and the classic proportional multi-winner election problem in social choice.

sections.text: The assignment of indivisible elements to multiple agents is a fundamental problem in many areas, including computer science, economics and operations research. Understanding the properties of the underlying algorithms is an important aspect to ensure that all participating agents are satisfied with their assignments and do not attempt to misrepresent their preferences; a key area of the study for computational social choice [9]. One area close to many academic hearts is the issue of assigning papers to peer review speakers. The results of the assignment, journal and conference reviews can have a significant impact on the careers of scholars.

sections.heading: 4.1 Pareto Optimality
sections.text: An assignment agent S is preferred by a particular agent with respect to pairwise comparisons than the assignment T, if S is the result of replacing an item in T with a strictly preferred item. Note that the pairwise comparison relationship is transitive. An assignment is optimal with respect to pairwise comparisons if there is no other assignment that each agent weakly prefers and strictly prefers at least one agent. Lemma 1. Consider an agent i and two equally large assignments S and T. If S is then preferred with respect to pairwise comparisons at least as much as T is preferred with i, then S will yield at least as much OWA value as T for each OWA vector, whether it increases or decreases. Note that S can be considered a transformation of T in which each item j is replaced by a different item that is at least as preferred. Therefore, the value of the item either remains the same or increases. In both cases, the corresponding agent is multiplied by the OWA value.

sections.text: In this proof, we use the most general formulations of our problem, using the values of the upper and lower pro-agent capacities, which can be different for each object. We reduce our problem to the problem of finding a minimum of feasible costs in a diagram with higher and lower capacities on the edges, which is a polynomial problem. Furthermore, we know that the flow is integral as long as all edge capacities are integral, even if we have real value-added costs [2].

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: We have proposed and provided algorithms for the novel idea of an Σ -OWA allocation. Σ -OWA allocation using decreasing OWA vectors gives the central organizer a "slider" to move from maximizing benefit to a more computationally efficient package with greater maximum allocation. An important open question for future work is the search for axiomatic characterizations for good OWA vectors. Furthermore, the OWA method and all the methods we have studied treat CPAP objects as beneficial. Generally, reviewers at a conference want to review less, not more, work. Consequently, it would be interesting to examine CPAP from the perspective of housework as it is called in the economic literature.
